Award.AwardTitle: Structural Response in Transient Winds of Hurricanes and Downbursts

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The assurance of public safety and the integrity of bridges and infrastructure during hurricanes and downbursts require accurate modeling of wind-induced effects. The transient characteristics of extreme winds are neither well understood nor characterized, which makes pre-event analysis difficult. This project pursues fundamental research to develop analytical model to analyze structural response in hurricane and downburst winds. Results will contribute to design standards that are used to assess response of flexible structures. A wind-field simulator will be developed and deployed as an on-line tool to enable designers, researchers and educators to simulate the effects of hurricane and downburst winds.

The primary goal of the research is to develop effective analysis tool to characterize and simulate the nonstationary wind-velocity fields and transient wind-load effects during non-synoptic events of hurricanes and downbursts. A systematic time-frequency analysis and synthesis framework, which can integrate the time-invariant (traditional) and/or time-variant spatial coherence into the simulated nonstationary wind-velocity fields, will be developed. The framework will facilitate an understanding of the underlying physics of transient wind-load effects for wind-structure interaction analysis. The study will assess the impact of nonstationary wind inputs in terms of their static, quasi-static and dynamic effects on structural response, and investigate modification of aerodynamic parameters. Joint acceptance functions, based on the nonstationary wind fields with various spatial coherences, and their effects on structural response will be examined. The Hilbert and wavelet techniques will be employed for the analysis and synthesis of nonstationary wind-velocity fields, and their efficacy will be assessed. The nonstationary features of hurricanes and downbursts will be investigated using data from field measurements, experiments, and numerical simulations. The transient aerodynamics will be illustrated using flexible bridges, with results also being relevant to the assessment of buildings and other structures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The assurance of structural safety and reliability under extreme winds requires accurate modeling of wind-induced effects. This heavily relies on our understanding of structural aerodynamics (from wind inputs to load outputs) and the nature of non-synoptic winds and hurricanes (characteristics of wind inputs). This project advanced effective analysis tools for better characterizing and simulating the nonstationary wind velocity fields and transient wind load effects during hurricanes and non-synoptic wind events (e.g., thunderstorm downbursts). While the nonstationary (transient) features of extreme wind events present significant importance for the accurate modeling of wind-induced effects on buildings, bridges and other structures, they were neither fully understood nor well captured in conventional analysis procedures.

 

To accomplish the goal, a systematic time-frequency analysis and synthesis framework, which can integrate the time-invariant (traditional) and/or time-variant spatial coherence into the simulated nonstationary wind velocity fields, was developed. More specifically, the Hilbert transform and wavelet packet decomposition techniques was utilized to offer a viable framework on simulation of nonstationary wind fields with time-variant spatial correlation. Furthermore, the non-iterative simultaneous matrix diagonalization (SMD) was introduced into the Hilbert-wavelet-based scheme to avoid solving nonlinear equation sets, and hence to significantly improve simulation efficiency. As a result, an efficient, online nonstationary-wind-field simulator was developed to provide researchers and designers with online analysis and synthesis of nonstationary wind fields during non-synoptic events and hurricanes. The developed time-frequency analysis and synthesis framework has also facilitated the understanding of the underlying physics of transient wind load effects in wind-structure interactions. It was found that the building responses corresponding to the time-varying correlation case were generally larger than those of the time-invariant case.

 

The effects of nonstationarity on the structural aerodynamics have been investigated based on semi-empirical linear, hybrid nonlinear and generalized hybrid nonlinear models, where the significant contribution of the time-varying mean wind speed to the effective angle of attack and hence to the nonlinear buffeting response was highlighted. The simulation results indicated it is important to consider the nonstationary transient effects for a more accurate simulation of bluff-body aerodynamics. To this end, the conventional one-dimensional indicial response function for the synoptic winds was extended to the two-dimensional indicial response function for the non-synoptic or transient winds. The results based on the numerical examples showed that the transient nature could significantly modify the aerodynamics of the wind-structure interaction system.

 

The project resulted in the education of 3 PhD students, and several undergraduate students and one high-school student have actively participated in the research study.
